Graphical abstract The La-N-C with micropores has a unique LaN4O moiety, which not only acts as an efficient active site for ORR but also induces the carbon atom near the graphitic N as another active site for ORR. Transition metal-nitrogen-carbon (M−N−C) with 3d transition metals as noble metal-free catalyzing oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) electrocatalysts still face critical challenges in activity and durability due to the Fenton effect associated with these metals in practical application. To tackle the issue, herein, we report Fenton-inactive rare earth metal La-N-C with dual active sites for efficient ORR, which was synthesized by pyrolyzing a mixed complexing compound of 1,10-phenanthroline as ligand with LaCl3 and MgCl2 as an activation agent. The as-synthesized La-N-C features an abundant microporous structure with atomically dispersed LaN4O moieties as new active sites, exhibiting outstanding ORR performance. Its half-wave potentials are 0.92 and 0.76 V in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 respectively, and only a 10 mV half-wave potential loss after 50 K cycles in 0.1 M KOH, achieving the highest level of current non-3d M−N−C ORR electrocatalysts. Meanwhile, the ORR activity is further validated by efficient performance with a power density output of 211 and 480 mW cm−2 on a single Zn-air battery and proton exchange membrane fuel cell respectively. Furthermore, theoretical calculations confirm that the unique LaN4O moiety adjacent to the microspore vacancy with graphitic N dopant not only presents a negative shift of the La 5d orbitals, significantly lowering the adsorption energy of *OOH in ORR, but also induces the carbon atom near the graphitic N as one more active site for ORR. This work highlights the potential application of La-N-C as an efficient ORR catalyst in green energy conversion devices. Keywords Metal-nitrogen-carbon Fenton-inactive single La atoms Oxygen reduction reaction Fuel cells Zn-Air batteries 1 Introduction In the past decades, metal-air batteries and H2-powered fuel cells that convert chemical energy into electricity via an electrochemical process have aroused significant interest as green power sources to address the environmental and energy challenges linked to the excessive consumption of fossil fuel owing to their high energy conversion efficiency and zero CO2 emission [1]. In the devices, the energy conversion efficiency is mainly limited by the sluggish oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) via a 4-e transfer process at the cathode [2], compared with the counterparts at the anode. So far, commercial Pt-based catalysts are still playing a dominant role in boosting ORR in the successful demonstration of these devices. However, the high cost of Pt with scarce resource creates a serious obstacle to their widespread application [3]. To address the issue, it is critical to develop non-precious metal candidates for ORR to promote the large-scale commercialization of such energy conversion devices [4]. Transition metal-nitrogen-carbon (M−N−C) catalysts have been intensively investigated as one of the most promising Pt-free alternatives in recent years due to their competitive ORR performance [5]. M−N−C exhibits a unique configuration of metal atom coordinated by surrounding N dopants in carbon (MN x moiety) as the active site for ORR, which is distinctive from conventional nano-sized metal-based catalysts [6]. The specific characteristic endows M−N−C with a wide and flexible platform for developing ORR catalysts. On the one hand, the ORR activity on M−N−C is dependent on the elements of the central metal atom [7]. So far, a vast amount of M−N−Csbased 3d transitional metals including Fe, and Co have been screened out as promising ORR catalysts [3,8]. On the other hand, the performance of M−N−C for ORR is also enhanced by introducing non-N atoms (B, O, S, P) into carbon, which can promote localized electron transfer and alter the electronic structure of the central metal atoms [9,10]. Even though atomically dispersed M−N−C catalysts have shown great promise for ORR, in particular, M−N−C catalysts based on Fe [11]. However, there is a hidden trouble that Fe is also prone to initiate a Fenton reaction with H2O2 generated from incomplete ORR [12] in a practical application, resulting in the rapid degradation of M−N−C catalysts [13]. To tackle the issue, new attempts have been performed based on less Fenton-active metals including Zn, Mn, Zr, Sb et al [2,4,6,14,15]. However, the overall performance of these new kinds of M−N−Cs is far away from the highest level of Fe-N-C. Compared to extensively reported M−N−C with 3d, 4d, and 5d traditional transition metals, rare earth elements typically possess larger ionic radius and unique 4f and 5d electronic structures [16,17]. Besides, the electron shielding effect of rare earth elements is effective enough to attract the electrons of the surrounding atoms to form a stable complex [18,19], which provides a special view for the design of rare earth M−N−C. In fact, recent studies have revealed the promising application prospects of rare earth elements (Y, Ce, Gd, La et al.) for ORR [16,18,20,21]. Unfortunately, the REM-N-Cs reported for ORR still encounter the dilemma that the performance is far less than the current stage of M−N−C with Fe and Co [22,23]. The most possible reason would be ascribed to the specific physicochemical properties of the rare earth elements such as the inert 4f electrons, the more negative reduction potentials, the larger atomic radii, and the highly unsaturated coordination environments, making it difficult to effectively form single atom REM-N-C using the current strategy of synthesizing M−N−C with 3d metals [24]. La as the first element of the lanthanide family has empty 4f orbitals and low d electron density with a weak capability for the Fenton reaction [18,19]. Nevertheless, the fact that La is easily oxidized by oxygen and has a big atomic radius makes it challenging to obtain atomically dispersed La-N-C [21]. To solve the problem, in this work, we report a microspore vacancy-enhanced La-N-C with axial O ligand for boosting ORR, which was prepared via a new strategy of pyrolyzing a nitrogen-containing chelate compound of 1,10-phenanthroline with La3+ under the assistance of MgCl2 as an activation agent. Thanks largely to the strong complexing capability of 1,10-phenanthroline with La3+ and the unique role of generating micropores of MgCl2, the obtained single atom La-N-C not only exhibits new active sites of LaN4O moieties with rich micropores doped by graphitic N dopants with an enhanced hybridization of 5d and 4f orbitals of La, significantly decreasing the reaction energy barrier of ORR, but also processes another active site induced by the charging of C atom adjacent to graphitic N for ORR. Under the coupling effect, the La-N-C demonstrates exceptional ORR performance with a half-wave potential of 0.92 V and a tiny loss of 10 mV after 50,000-cycle accelerated durability testing in alkaline medium, exceeding all reported non-3d M−N−Cs and reaching the most advanced Fe-N-Cs reported. Furthermore, the practical single PEMFC and the Zn-air battery assembled with La-N-C exhibit a high power density of 480 and 211 mW cm−2 respectively, indicating its potential application as a cathode for ORR in energy conversion devices. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of La-N-C with dispersed La atoms In the synthesis, 0.02 mol of 1,10-phenanthroline, 0.01 mol of LaCl3·7H2O, and 0.06 mol of MgCl2·6H2O were uniformly mixed with 4 mL of H2O in a ball milling jar at 500 r min−1 for 10 h to form the suspension paste. After drying at 120 ℃, the sample was heated to 450 ℃ for 1 h in N2 to further remove the H2O in the sample, followed by pyrolysis at 670 ℃ for 2 h to obtain a gray solid block. Subsequently, the gray solid was ground into a fine powder and proceeded with 7 mL of H2O for another ball-milling process at 500 r min−1 for 2 h. The sample was then treated with 0.5 M H2SO4 at 50 ℃ for 4 h to remove unstable metal compositions. The resulting black powder was then calcined at 900 ℃ for 1 h in N2 to obtain the final La-N-C, which was labeled as La-N-C-2. Compared to La-N-C-2, La-N-Cs with less or more La atoms were prepared by the identical procedure using 0.008 mol and 0.012 mol of LaCl3·7H2O, which were named La-N-C-1 and La-N-C-3 respectively. Meanwhile, pure N-doped carbon without La (N-C) was also synthesized without adding LaCl3·7H2O during synthesis. 2.2 Physical characterization Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) with Hitachi SU 8220 was used to observe the macro-level morphology of samples, and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) on Titan Cubed Themis G2 300 was employed to observe the lattice structures of carbon in samples and dispersion of La atoms. X-ray diffraction patterns (XRD) of samples were collected by a D8 Advance with Cu Kα (λ = 1.54178 Å) to analyze the crystal phases of carbon and La species. The quantification and chemical states of the elements in samples were determined on an X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS) of Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha. The surface areas and pore structures of samples were quantified on Micromeritics ASAP 2460 in N2. The defect degrees of carbon in sampleswereevaluated withthe Raman spectrometer ofLab RAM HR Evolution (Horiba) at 532 nm. The X-ray absorption fine structure spectra (XAFS) of La L-edge in samples were obtained on the RapidXAFS 2 M. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The oxygen reduction activity of samples was assessed by a rotating disk electrode (RRDE) with the PINE electrochemical station. In the cell, a graphite rod instead of a Pt sheet was served as the counter electrode to eliminate the possible influence caused by the dissolution of Pt, and a commercial reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) within the same electrolyte was used as the reference electrode to alleviate the errors caused by the correction of the other reference electrode, while the working electrode was a glassy carbon electrode with Pt ring. As for the preparation of the working electrode, a homogeneous catalyst ink was prepared by dispersing 5.0 mg of the catalyst into a solution containing 20 μL of 5 wt% Nafion and 480 μL of isopropanol in the presence of ultra-sonication. Subsequently, 15 μL of this ink was then uniformly deposited onto the glassy carbon electrode to form a film with a catalyst loading of 0.6 mg cm−2. The commercial Pt/C (Tanaka, 46.7% Pt/C) electrode with a Pt loading of 50 μg cm−2 was also prepared for comparison. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed in both 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 electrolyte to obtain the ORR activity at a rotation rate of 1600 r min−1 and a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 in the potential range between 1.2 and 0.05 V. The peroxide yield (H2O2%) and corresponding electron transfer numbers (n) of the samples for ORR were determined using the following Eqs. (1) and (2) respectively. (1) H2O2% = 200 × I r/(I r + I d) (2) n = 4 × I d / I d + I r / N where I r and I d represent the absolute values of the Pt ring current and the disk current respectively, and N (the current collection efficiency) is 0.38.In addition, the mass activity (MA) and turnover frequency (TOF) of the catalysts are calculated from the following equations M A = J k m T O F = J k × N e m × N A / M m e t a l where m is the mass of metal in the electrocatalyst coated on the working electrode (obtained by the ICP), J k is the kinetic current density, N e (6.24 × 1018) is the electron number per Coulomb, N A (6.022 × 1023) is the Avogadro constant and M metal is the mass per mole of metal. The durability of the samples was evaluated by conducting cyclic voltammetry (CV) in the potential range of 0.6–1.0 V vs. RHE at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1 in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4. 2.4 Fabrication of Zn-Air battery and tests In the homemade Zn-air battery, the cathodes were prepared by coating 1.25 mg cm−2 of La-N-C or commercial Pt/C onto the water-proof carbon paper with an active area of 0.785 cm2, meanwhile, a polished Zn foil was used as the anode and the electrolyte was the mixed solution of 6.0 M KOH and 0.2 M zinc acetate. The battery performance was evaluated with I-V polarization curves obtained from the open circuit voltage of 0.2 V. The scan rate was 10 mV s−1 and the flow rate was 100 mL min−1 for O2. The specific capacity was measured by a constant current discharge test at 10 mA cm−2.The durability tests were assessed by CV with 1000 cycles in the voltage range between 1 V to 0.6 V at a scan rate of 100 mV s−1. 2.5 Fabrication of a single proton exchange membrane fuel cell and tests The membrane assemble electrode (MEA) with La-N-C-2 as cathode, Pt/C as anode, and NRE 211 as polymer electrolyte was fabricated for a single proton exchange membranefuel cell (PEMFC) test. The cathode with 2.0 mg cm−2 of La-N-C-2 was obtained by spraying the catalyst ink (100 mg of La-N-C-2 catalyst,857.0 mgof 5.0 wt% Nafion solution, 10 mL of isopropanol) uniformly onto the carbon paper coated by with microporous gas diffusion layer by a spray gun and then dried at 80 °C for 10 min. The anode with the0.2 mg cm−2 of the commercial Pt/C (46.7 wt% Pt/C, Tanaka) was prepared in the same way. The membrane electrode assemblies (MEAs) were prepared by pressing the anode and cathode on both sides of an NRE 211 membrane at 135 ℃. Inthetest,100 % humidified H2 and O2 (400 mLmin−1) were supplied into the cell (80 ℃) with a back pressure of 150.0 kPa. 2.6 Density functional theory（DFT）calculation To understand the role of atomic La-N-C for ORR, the La-N-C models with various structures were built up by Materials Studio and calculated based on first principles via the dimensional Vienna ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) [25,26]. In the calculations, the interaction between nuclei and valence electrons was expressed using a projection-enhanced wave (PAW), and the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) level was used to be the exchange–correlation potential [27]. The Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) analysis was performed by using the LOBSTER software [28,29]. The DFT + U approach was applied with a U value of 6 for all the models [30]. The plane-wave energy cut-off was 480 eV, and the energy convergence criterion for electronic relaxation was 1 × 10−5 eV. All the calculations were based on the spin polarization. The final force on each atom was 0.01 eV Å−1, and the K point was set to 3 × 3 × 1. Meanwhile, to achieve sufficient space for geometry relaxations, a vacuum space of 20 Å in the z-axis was applied. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of La-N-C catalyst Fig. 1 a shows the schematic diagram for the synthesis of the La-N-C catalysts via the following three key steps: 1) complexing La3+ with 1,10-phenanthroline as ligands with rich C and N sources in the presence of MgCl2 as the micropore generator by a ball-milling process; 2) pyrolyzing the complexed compound with La3+ at elevated temperatures in N2; 3) achieving the final La-N-C after by removing unstable species followed by second pyrolysis. Fig. 1b–g show the fine structural characteristics by TEM observation of La-N-C synthesized using the process in Fig. 1a, represented by La-N-C-2. The high-resolution TEM image in Fig. 1b shows that La-N-C-2 is filled with a short-range ordered graphitic structure, indicating that there are abundant defects. Meanwhile, the elemental mapping in Fig. 1c, d confirms that the elements of C, N, La, and O are uniformly dispersed throughout the La-N-C. Furthermore, in the HADDF image with a double-aberration corrected microscope (Fig. 1e), the presence of La atoms can be directly observed where La atoms appear as bright and individual spots, while the 3D atom-overlapping Gaussian-function fitting map in Fig. 1f exactly confirms the single La atom anchoring in the carbon matrix. Additionally, electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) elemental maps of La-N-C-2, as shown in Fig. 1g and Fig. S1, further verify that the observed bright and individual spots correspond to La atoms, which are surrounded by N atoms, C atoms, and O atoms. The result indicates that the moieties-based La atom as central metal should be comprised of LaN x O y C z . To explore the geometric coordination structure around La atoms, X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) analyses were employed. As shown in Fig. 1h, the near-edge structure of La-N-C-2 is distinctly different from La foil, LaN, and La2O3, in which it exhibits a maximum peak intensity (∼5487 eV), exhibiting a peak intensity that obviously exceeds that of La foil while being close to LaN and La2O3, indicating that the oxidation state of La in La-N-C-2 is approaching + 3. Meanwhile, the EXAFS of La-N-C-2 in Fig. 1i reveals that there is a strong peak at approximately 2.02 Å, which is significantly smaller than La-La pathways at about 2.2 and 4.7 Å in La foil and bigger than the LaO bonds (1.9 Å) in La2O3 and LaN bonds (2.0 Å) in LaN, indicating that La exists as the state of a single atom with a specific configuration with LaN and LaO bonds [31,32], further confirming the presence of isolated La sites identified by the above HADDF-STEM and EELS results. The fitting curves in the EXAFS R-space (Fig. 1j) show that the specific coordinative structure of La atoms in the La-N-C-2 catalyst is coordinated by four N atoms and one O atom. The details of EXAFS fitting parameters are listed in Table S2. Furthermore, the EXAFS wavelet transforms (WT) plots in Fig. 1k–n for La-N-C-2, La2O3, La foil and LaN respectively visually show that the contour plot of La-N-C-2 exhibits a maximum intensity at ∼3.9 Å−1, which is different from the structural characteristics of La foil (7.25 Å−1), LaN (3.7 Å−1) and La2O3 (3.3 Å−1). The above features indicate that La exists as mono-nuclear centers, forming stable monoatomic structures with N and O atoms. The SEM images of N-C, La-N-C-1, La-N-C-2, and La-N-C-3 in Fig. S2 illustrate they have similar morphologies with rich pores, in contrast, the La-N-C obtained without MgCl2 presents a relatively dense structure in Fig. S3, demonstrating the critical role of MgCl2 as an activating agent to generate more pore structures in pyrolysis. Fig. 2 a shows the structural characteristics of La-N-Cs with different ratios of La ions and the N-C identified by XRD. All samples exhibit two obvious diffraction peaks at around 26° and 42.2°, which are attributed to the [002] plane and [100] plane of the graphitic carbon respectively [33], and there are no obvious diffraction peaks of other La species, further verifying that La detected in TEM observation exits at atomic dispersion. Meanwhile, it is also found that the peak position of [002] lane of La-N-Cs has a slightly negative shift to low diffraction angles, compared with the N-C without La, in which it appears at around 26° for N-C, and accompanying the increase of adding ratio of La, it then shifts to 25.7° for La-N-C-1, 25.1° for La-N-C-2, and 24.8° for La-N-C-3. This shift to low angles may be attributed to the insertion of a larger atomic radius of La atoms into graphitic lattices, leading to a decrease in the intensity and broadening of the diffraction peaks during the second pyrolysis and thus further affecting the intrinsic activity of the La-N-Cs. In addition, to understand the formation of La-N-Cs, the La-N-C obtained at various steps in the synthesis was also analyzed by XRD. As shown in Fig. 2b, the XRD pattern of La-N-C-2 obtained at the first step of pyrolysis reveals that there are two metal oxide diffractions which are from MgO at 42.9° and 62.3° as well as the crystal phase of LaOCl at 12.9°, 25.2°, 30.7°, 33.9°, 40.6°, 44.0°, 50.3°, 51.3°, 56.7°, and 63.9°, demonstrating that the majority of LaCl3 and MgCl2 in the complexed precursor is converted into LaOCl and MgO during pyrolysis. Moreover, by further acid washing with the ball milling process, the aforementioned MgO and LaOCl species disappear. Inductively coupled plasma analysis confirmed the loading of La is 0.31 wt% and Mg is 0.10 wt% in La-N-C-2, indicating that the process can effectively remove the unstable species and form monoatomic La structures. After the following second calcination, the obtained La-N-C has a positive shift at the (002) diffraction peak, compared with that of La-N-C after acid treatment, suggesting that the second thermal treatment can decrease the defects, which would optimize the microstructure of La-N-C, enhancing the activity of the catalyst for ORR [34]. The Raman spectra of the metal-free N-C and the La-N-C catalysts reveal the defect characteristics. As indicated in Fig. 2c, all catalysts exhibit two characteristic peaks around 1350 and 1580 cm−1, which reflect the degree of distortion (D band) and graphitization (G band) of carbon materials respectively [6,35]. To obtain a more detailed structure, the D peak is further deconvoluted into four bands using Gaussian fitting, namely D1 (1350 cm−1), D2 (1620 cm−1), D3 (1485 cm−1), and D4 (1200 cm−1) respectively [6]. The D1/G peak area ratio for N-C is 2.13 for N-C, while the ratios are 2.28 for La-N-C-1, 2.5 for La-N-C-2, and 2.29 for La-N-C-3, respectively. The I D1/I G intensity ratios for N-C and different La-N-Cs with La-N-C-1, 2, and 3 catalysts are 1.36, 1.45, 1.63, and 1.54, respectively. The results indicate that introducing La can generate more defects and the defect degrees of La-N-C also depend on the ratio in the synthesis. Furthermore, from the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms shown in Fig. 2d, all samples have a significant adsorption and desorption behavior at the low relative pressure region, indicating that they are abundantly microporous. Meanwhile, the inset in Fig. 2d confirms the result that the N-C and La-N-Cs prepared in the presence of MgCl2 present an obvious characteristic of the micropore distribution region at around 1.0 nm. The corresponding Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas are 632.54 m2 g−1 for N-C, 956.01 m2 g−1 for La-N-C-1, 1044.92 m2 g−1 for La-N-C-2, and 908.67 m2 g−1 for La-N-C-3. In contrast, La-N-C without MgCl2, as shown in Fig. S4, has ultra-low BET surface area down to 6.85 m2 g−1 and no obvious pore structure, indicating that the presence of MgCl2 in the synthesis of La-N-C plays a dominant role for generating micropore in the carbon matrix, wherein MgCl2 would be hydrolyzed with crystal H2O to form MgO at the elevated temperature, which can etch the carbon to produce the micopore due to its nature of corrosiveness [36]. It is believed that the micropore in M−N−C is beneficial to expose the active sites for ORR [37]. In addition, compared with N-C, the introduction of La significantly increases the specific surface areas, which is consistent with the Raman analysis and indicates more defects. Fig. 3 shows XPS analyses of N-C and La-N-Cs to clarify their surface chemical states. The high-resolution C 1s XPS spectra in Fig. 3a can be deconvoluted into five peaks at 284.7, 285.4, 286.3, 288.9, and 290.8 eV, corresponding to C–C, C–N, C–O, C=N/C=O, and π*-π* transitions respectively [38]. This confirms the presence of nitrogen and oxygen functionalities within the carbon matrix. Similarly, in Fig. 3b, the N 1s XPS spectra can usually be fitted into five peaks at 398.23, 399.7, 400.82, and 402.79 eV, which are attributed to pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, graphitic-N, and oxidized-N species [39], respectively, besides that, there are other bonds at 399.06 eV, which should be contributed to La–N [40]. Meanwhile, it is found that the total content of N in N-C is 4.93%, as shown in Table S1 on the element contents obtained by XPS full-survey of all samples. In comparison, the values in La-N-Cs are 5.78%, 7.01%, and 6.19% for La-N-C-1, La-N-C-2, and La-N-C-3, indicating that introducing La can increase the N content, displaying that La can capture N with the specific coordination. Meanwhile, there is a significant difference between the specific N dopants in all samples. As shown in Fig. 3e, the graphitic nitrogen content of the catalysts La-N-C-1 to La-N-C-3 initially increases and then decreases, with La-N-C-2 exhibiting the highest proportion of graphitic nitrogen at 40% while the pyrrole nitrogen content is increasing from 6 % to 15 % in Fig. 3e. Meanwhile, the pyridinic-N and graphitic-N contents in all of the La-N-C-2 catalytic materials are significantly higher than that of pyrrolic-N, which contributes to enhanced stability during testing. Fig. 3c shows the high-resolution O 1s XPS spectra can be fitted into four peaks at 529.79, 531.41, 532.71, and 533.98 eV, corresponding to La–O, O–H, C=O, and C–O [39], indicating the existence of one more coordination with O of La atom in La-N-C beside the coordination of La and N. The La 3d 5/2 doublet splitting of La-N-C is about 3.4 eV in Fig. 3d, which differs from the lanthanum oxide (4.5 eV) [41]. This suggests that it is not merely a La–O coordination structure. Considering the atomic content of the La–O peak, the atomic content of the La–N peak, and the atomic content of La atoms (0.14%) together, it would be deduced that La is most likely coordinated by four N atoms and an axial O ligand. 3.2 Electrochemical performance for ORR Fig. 4 a demonstrates ORR LSV curves of N-C, La-N-Cs, and Fe-N-C prepared by the same method of synthesizing La-N-Cs using 1,10-phenanthroline and FeCl3 with their molar ratio of 2:1 and commercial Pt/C in 0.1 M KOH. Among them, all La-N-Cs exhibit a remarkable ORR performance, which completely exceeds N-C, indicating that introducing La atom exactly enhance ORR. Meanwhile, the La-N-C-2 shows the best ORR performance, outperforming the Fe-N-C and even commercial Pt/C. Concretely, as shown in Fig. 4b (the comparison of key parameters including half-wave potential (E 1/2) and kinetic current density (J k) at 0.9 V), La-N-C-2 has the highest E 1/2 of 0.92 V and J k of 14.62 mA cm−2, which is 30 mV and 13.4 times higher than those of Pt/C (E 1/2 = 0.86 V, J k = 1.09 mA cm−2) respectively. Meanwhile, La-N-C-1 (E 1/2 = 0.89 V, J k = 3.92 mA cm−2) and La-N-C-3 (E 1/2 = 0.91 V, J k = 7.68 mA cm−2) also exhibit higher ORR activity than Pt/C. These results confirm that La-N-Cs have excellent performance for ORR. On the other hand, Fe-N-C as the standard for the M−N−C for ORR also has high E 1/2 of 0.89 V and J k of 5.7 mA cm−2, indicating that the strategy of synthesizing La-N-Cs has great potential of developing other M−N−Cs. In addition, as shown in Fig. 4c, La-N-C-2 has the lowest Tafel slope (56.01 mV dec−1), indicating the fastest reaction kinetics, compared with La-N-C-1 (57.12 mV dec−1), La-N-C-3 (56.08 mV dec−1), N-C (78.77 mV dec−1), Fe-N-C (67.4 mV dec−1) and Pt/C (59.92 mV dec−1). Correspondingly, La-N-C-2 exhibits an H2O2 yield of less than 3% and an electron-transfer number of 3.94–3.99, as shown in Fig. 4d, which is better than Fe-N-C prepared by the same method and approaching Pt/C, indicating it has a preferred 4e-ORR process. The electrochemical surface areas (ECSA) were assessed by the double-layer capacitance (C dl). As shown in Figs. S5 and S6, all the La-N-C catalysts have significantly larger electrochemical ECSAs than N-C, and La-N-C-2 exhibits the highest C dl of 73.07 mF cm−2. Fig. S7a shows the mass activity (MA) of La-N-C-2 at 0.88 V is 15.20 A mg−1, which is higher than Pt/C (0.19 A mg−1), and the turnover frequencies (TOF) of La-N-C-2 is up to 21.88 s−1 at 0.88 V, which is about 55 times higher than that of Pt/C (0.39 s−1), revealing the excellent ORR activity of La-N-C-2. Moreover, in Fig. 4e, La-N-C-2 presents a superior long-term catalytic stability with only a 10 mV decay in E 1/2 after 50,000 cycles, which is one-fifth of the decay for Pt/C. Meanwhile, Fig. 4f demonstrates the Raman spectra of La-N-C-2 before and after the durability test. No significant changes in the G and D peaks can be found. Meanwhile, the La-N-C-2 displays only 28 % MA lost after 50,000 cycles in Fig. S7b, much lower than that of Pt/C. The both results indicate the structural stability of La-N-C-2. Compared with recently reported advanced M−N−Cs based Fe, Co, and other non-3d metals (Fig. 4g), the activity and durability of La-N-C-2 can achieve the highest level for overall ORR performance and approach the best level of developed Fe-N-C, indicating that La-N-C developed in the work holds a great promise as a new-structured catalyst for ORR. To examine whether the La atom is the active center atom in La-N-C for promoting ORR, a new La-N-C sample was prepared by impregnating LaCl3 into N-C followed by the calcination at 900 ℃. It can be seen in Fig. S8 that the E 1/2 of La-N-C with ion implantation is elevated by 30 mV, compared with that of N-C, indicating that the La atom plays a key role in the construction of active sites for ORR activity. Meanwhile, a poisoning experiment was carried out using 0.05 M 1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane-1,4,7,10-tetraacetic acid (DOTA), which enables the complexing with La atom in La-N-C and thus degrades the activity of La-N-C. As shown in Fig. S9, after treatment with DOTA, the E 1/2 of La-N-C decreases significantly by 40 mV. Hence, through the two tests, it can be concluded that the La atom essentially works as an active site for ORR. On the other hand, Fig. S10 presents their ORR performance in 0.5 M H2SO4. Among N-C and other La-N-Cs, the La-N-C-2 still possesses the highest activity with the E 1/2 of 0.76 V, which is 120 mV higher than that of the N-C catalyst and lower Pt/C (0.84 V), demonstrating it can work well for ORR in acid media. Additionally, Fig. S11 shows that the La-N-C-2 after second pyrolysis has a significantly increased ORR performance in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4, indicating that the second pyrolysis is beneficial for improving the ORR activity of the catalysts due to the fact that the second pyrolysis can further optimize the microstructure revealed by its less defects than that obtained by first pyrolysis and acid-leaching treatment (2.7 for D1/G) in Fig. S12. To evaluate the performance of the La-N-C-2 for practical application, a single Zn-air battery with it as cathode was fabricated, as shown in Fig. 4h. The battery with La-N-C-2 catalyst deliver a maximum power density of 211 mW cm−2 in Fig. 4i, which is superior to that with the same-loading Pt/C catalyst. Even after 1,000 cycles, the La-N-C-2 still retains a power density of 184 mW cm−2 with only 27 mW cm−2 loss, which is significantly less than that of battery with Pt/C (61 mW cm−2 decay from original 159 to 98 mW cm−2, demonstrating its high durability. This further confirms the result of La-N-C-2 in the half-cell test with 0.1 M KOH (Fig. 4e). Additionally, the specific capacity of the La-N-C-2 catalyst is 809.1 mA h gZn −1, as shown in Fig. 4j, which is significantly higher than that of Pt/C (770 mA h gZn −1), indicating the promising application potential of La-N-C-2 in Zn-air batteries. Moreover, Fig. S13 demonstrates the performance of the La-N-C-2 in a single PEMFC. Compared to Pt/C with a power density of 670 mW cm−2 at a loading of 0.05 mg cm−2, the La-N-C-2 exhibits a power density of 480 mW cm−2 at a loading of 2 mg cm−2. The durability in Fig. S14 shows that the La-N-C-2 still generates a certain level of 350 and 270 mW cm−2 after 50 cycles and 300 cycles respectively, indicating that La-N-C holds great promise for the application in harsh acid electrolytes. These results further confirm the bright application prospects of La-N-C in both Zn-air batteries and PEMFCs. 3.3 Revealing ORR mechanism of La-N-C by DFT To further reveal the advanced ORR performance of the La-N-C catalyst, DFT calculations were employed. According to the typical characteristics of La-N-C revealed by a series of characterizations of TEM, XPS, and XAS, the models with LaN4O moiety and abundant microspore with various N dopants of graphitic N, pyridinic N, and pyrrolic N were built up, as shown in Fig. 5 a–e, including LaN4O without micropore vacancy (La-N-C) and LaN4O with micropore and LaN4O with micropore doped by graphitic N, pyridinic N, and pyrrolic N, which were named as La-N-C, La-N-C-mic, La-N-C-mic-Graph, La-N-C-mic-Pyrid, La-N-C-mic-Pyrro respectively. Firstly, the effect of surrounding micro-environments on LaN4O moiety was calculated. As shown in Fig. S15 (charge density differences analysis), the charges of La atoms in the 5 models are quite different, in which, the Bader charge of La in La-N-C-mic-Graph has the lowest value of 1.833 e, which is remarkably less than La-N-C-mic (1.894 e), La-N-C-mic-Pyrid (1.938 e), La-N-C-mic-Pyrro (1.900 e) and La-N-C (1.967 e). The results indicate that the electronic structure of LaN4O moiety can be affected by the surrounding environmental structures including micropore vacancy and its derived configurations with various N dopants, which would regulate the interaction of La with the adsorption of intermediates produced in ORR process. Their projected partial density of states (PDOS) in Fig. 5f further demonstrates that the existence of micropores significantly promotes the negative shift in the PDOS of La 5d, compared with La-N-C without micropores. Meanwhile, the introduction of different types of N also promotes the hybridization of 5d and 4f orbitals of La compared to La-N-C-mic and thus improve the charge transfer efficiency. In particular, the La 5d orbitals in the La-N-C-mic-Graph model presents a negative shift, which is beneficial for modulating the adsorption and desorption of intermediates. Fig. S16 shows the ORR energy profiles on these models at 0 V, in which, all five models exhibit a continuous downward trend, while the La-N-C-mic-Graph model displays a more pronounced decline in the desorption energy of *OOH, indicating that La-N-C-mic-Graph more readily achieves the desorption of *OOH. Meanwhile, when the potential is 1.23 V in Fig. 5g, the La-N-C-mic-Graph model exhibits the lowest adsorption free energy of *OOH to *O (0.48 eV), while the values are 0.53 eV for La-N-C-mic (* to *OOH), 0.72 eV for La-N-C-mic-Pyrid (* to *OOH),0.76 eV for La-N-C-mic-Pyrro (* to *OOH) and 0.8 eV for La-N-C (* to *OOH) respectively, indicating a significant enhancement in electroactivity toward the ORR process. To further understanding the enhanced ORR, the Crystal Orbital Hamilton Population (COHP) of the 4 models with *OOH was calculated respectively. As displayed in Fig. S17 and Table S3, the bonding states of *OOH in the La-N-C-mic-Graph model (1.45 eV for ICOHP) are higher than those of La-N-C-mic-Pyrid (1.28 eV for ICOHP) and La-N-C-mic-Pyrro (1.32 eV for ICOHP), but lower than those of La-N-C-mic (1.48 eV for ICOHP), indicating it is beneficial for the adsorption and desorption process for ORR. Fig. 5i, j and Fig. S18 illustrate the La 5d band predominantly contributes to the bonding states near the Fermi level between 0 and − 4.5 eV, rather than the 6 s or 4f orbitals. Generally, the microspore with various N dopants is conducive to the f-d-p orbital hybridization, accelerating ORR reaction kinetics and *OOH desorption. On the other hand, the effect of LaN4O moiety on the surrounding carbon atoms for ORR was also calculated. Traditionally, the activity of ORR on carbon-based metal-free catalysts is influenced by the location of dopants, positions and carbon defects [50]. Fig. 6 a illustrates the model structure and schematic ORR process of La-N-C-mic-Graph-C17 and N-C-mic-Graph-C17. Interestingly, the Bader charge of the C17 atom in the La-N-C-mic-Graph-C17 model is 0.137 eV higher than that of the C17 of N-C-mic-Graph-C17 model, but 0.534 eV lower than that the C6 of La-N-C-mic-Pyrid model, and 0.28 eV lower than that of the C4 of La-N-C-mic-Pyrro model. It is interestingly found that C6 of La-N-C-mic-Pyrid and C4 of La-N-C-mic-Pyrro model do not suitable for ORR due to their unique electronic structure as shown in Fig. S15c, d. The new findings break the conventional understanding of N-doped carbon with pyridine as sites for ORR [51]. Furthermore, their PODS in Fig. 6c shows that some distinct peaks of the La-N-C-mic-Graph-C17 model are located closer to the Fermi level compared to the N-C-mic-Graph-C17 model, indicating that La-N-C-mic-Graph-C17 exhibits superior electron transfer capabilities and chemical reactivity. Thus, when U = 0 V, La-N-C-mic-Graph-C17 exhibits a relatively excellent downhill trend compared to the N-C-mic-Graph-C17 in Fig. 6d. At 1.23 V, the La-N-C-mic-Graph-C17 model exhibits adsorption-free energy of * to *OOH (0.56 eV) as the rate-determining step better than Graph-C17 (0.9 eV) in Fig. 6e. Through DFT calculations, it is found that the configuration of LaN4O with micropores exhibits exceptional ORR activity. The presence of graphitic N in the microspore significantly reduces the adsorption strength of *OOH, further improving the ORR activity of the LaN4O structure. In addition, the LaN4O also tune the electronic structure of carbon atoms in the micropore adjacent to graphitic N to generate another active site for ORR. The results also further explain well the underlying mechanism of La-N-C with rich micropore and graphic N dopant developed in the work for exceptional performance for ORR. Generally, compared with reported M−N−Cs, in this work, the La-N-C exhibits unique dual active sites for ORR, in which LaN4O moiety with micropore vacancy is not only active for ORR but also can tune the electronic structure of carbon atoms in the micropore adjacent to graphitic N to generate another active site for ORR, demonstrating excellent ORR performance under acid and alkaline media, along with high-performance output in PEMFCs and Zn air batteries. Additionally, the strategy for synthesizing La-N-C also provides a new route of developing other atomic rare metal catalysts for electrocatalysis. 4 Conclusions The microspore vacancy-enhanced La-N-C with specific LaN4O moieties has been successfully developed for efficient catalysis of ORR through the pyrolysis of a complexing compound of 1,10-phenanthroline with LaCl3 in the presence of MgCl2 as an activator. Attributed to the new synthetic strategy, the La-N-C features atomic LaN4O moieties dispersed in high-surface rich graphitic N-doped carbon with abundant micropores. Furthermore, the unique La-N(O) coordination with graphitized N enhances charge transfer efficiency, significantly reducing the adsorption energy of *OOH. Meanwhile, the presence of micropores with graphitic N dopants leads to substantial electronic modulation of the La-4f and La-5d orbitals, resulting in lowering the adsorption energy of *OOH and effectively promoting the ORR. Additionally, the LaN4O also tune the electronic structure of carbon atoms in the micropore adjacent to graphitic N to generate another active site for ORR. Due to their unique morphology and electronic structure, the La-N-C catalysts demonstrate high ORR performance with half-wave potentials of 0.92 and 0.76 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4, respectively. To our best knowledge, the activity of La-N-C developed in the work exceeds all newly developed non 3d M−N−C and competes with the best M−N−C with Fe. Furthermore, it also achieves high-performance of Zn-air battery and proton exchange membrane fuel cell as the cathode with the maximum power output of 211 and 480 mW cm−2, respectively. In summary, this work develops the rare earth La-N-C as a new class of active sites for efficient ORR, showing significant potential for practical applications in metal-air batteries and PEMFCs. It is also believed that it provides a straightforward approach for developing other atomic rare earth-N-C materials, avoiding the limitation of atomic radius in the conventional strategy of synthesizing M−N−C. coredata.dc:description: Transition metal-nitrogen-carbon (M−N−C) with 3d transition metals as noble metal-free catalyzing oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) electrocatalysts still face critical challenges in activity and durability due to the Fenton effect associated with these metals in practical application. To tackle the issue, herein, we report Fenton-inactive rare earth metal La-N-C with dual active sites for efficient ORR, which was synthesized by pyrolyzing a mixed complexing compound of 1,10-phenanthroline as ligand with LaCl3 and MgCl2 as an activation agent. The as-synthesized La-N-C features an abundant microporous structure with atomically dispersed LaN4O moieties as new active sites, exhibiting outstanding ORR performance. Its half-wave potentials are 0.92 and 0.76 V in 0.1 M KOH and 0.5 M H2SO4 respectively, and only a 10 mV half-wave potential loss after 50 K cycles in 0.1 M KOH, achieving the highest level of current non-3d M−N−C ORR electrocatalysts. Meanwhile, the ORR activity is further validated by efficient performance with a power density output of 211 and 480 mW cm−2 on a single Zn-air battery and proton exchange membrane fuel cell respectively. Furthermore, theoretical calculations confirm that the unique LaN4O moiety adjacent to the microspore vacancy with graphitic N dopant not only presents a negative shift of the La 5d orbitals, significantly lowering the adsorption energy of *OOH in ORR, but also induces the carbon atom near the graphitic N as one more active site for ORR. This work highlights the potential application of La-N-C as an efficient ORR catalyst in green energy conversion devices.
